Introduction
I currently study mainly the bionomics of solitary vespid wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae: Eumeninae and Masarinae). The second field of research is a faunistic and taxonomic inventory of these wasps of Russia and neighboring countries. I also study megachilid bees (Hymenoptera: Megachilidae) of European Russia (particularly, the North Caucasus). Finally, I also study taxonomy of orchids and some other plants of the Crimea and the North Caucasus.

What does anybody think about these "gynandromorphs"?
Question
  • Mar 2014
The question is could such specimens lay eggs? I just have not made a dissection of any of these to see whether they have ovaries but they can have them.
P.S. There is a mistake in the article. The second paragraph of the discussion is incorrect. The original text (before editing) was the following:
"Certain factor inducing so frequent occurrence of such gynandromorphs in Megachile is unknown. There are some data showed appearances of the male characters (e.g., antennae) in the bee females under the influence of Strepsiptera parasites [Popov, 1937]. But these parasites usually affect genitalia and bring on their abnormal development. However the parasites’ hypothesis was supported by Mitchell [1929] who had summarized all available at that time data on the sexually anomalies in the genus. In our case the mites are not being regarded as the possible cause because they have been discovered on normal females and males too." Of course, there are no Strepsiptera on Megachile.
